qas.question: Thomas and others sought to distinguish between what chromosome of Jewish priests and that of non-Jews?
What does the new "race science" call attention to the importance of?
What do people desire to use science to confirm?
What is fundamentally different from older notions of race?
How were older notions of race used?

answers.text: to explain differences in human behaviour or social status

context: As another example, she points to work by Thomas et al., who sought to distinguish between the <a0_0>Y<a0_0/> chromosomes of Jewish priests (Kohanim), (in Judaism, membership in the priesthood is passed on through the father's line) and the Y chromosomes of non-Jews. Abu el-Haj concluded that this new "race science" calls attention to the importance of "<a1_0>ancestry<a1_0/>" (narrowly defined, as it does not include all ancestors) in some religions and in popular culture, and people's desire to use science to confirm <a2_0>their claims about ancestry<a2_0/>; this "<a3_0>race science<a3_0/>", she argues, is fundamentally different from older notions of race that were used <a4_0>to explain differences in human behaviour or social status<a4_0/>:
